captions.text:
If there's one thing we can all agree on
it's that everybody hates hipsters, right?

You know, it's the common enemy that
we all have that will unite us,

that will remove all race and gender
boundaries and we will say we,

our humanity like Independence Day,
and we will fight against the hipsters.

Even the hipsters themselves
who, apparently,

don't even know that they are
hipsters will also hate hipsters.

Everybody is against the same
thing and its kind of,

it's kind of beautiful
in a way.

So you can imagine the horror
that you would experience

if you started noticing some these hipster-like
tendencies appearing in your life.

That, my friends, if I can still
call you friends after this,

is what I am suffering
from right now.

I think the biggest and most telling example
for me was when I bought those glasses.

I mean, just look at that.
To be wearing the glasses.

The actual Ray Band Wayfarers that you put
on something to turn it into a hipster.

This is-- That's how you turn Ariel into
Hipster Ariel by putting these on.

And yet, I am not going to do
anything about it.

Like, these were expensive glasses
and I think I look good in them.

This is when this worry started
for me was when I was

sitting in like a trendy
warehouse-type coffee bar,

looking around me thinking,
"Heh, there's a hipster there.

Oh, there another one.
Look at his funny mustache.

Uh...everyone is a hipster here.
Why am I here?"

So my interpretation of the hipster-like
personality constitutes a couple things.
First off: you like things ironically.

That, I think I can comfortably say
is something that I don't do.

I have my things that I like a lot and I like
maybe even to some people too much,

but I don't care 'cause
I like them.

That to me is a nerd, but then
there's the whole, you know,

"You know that thing that
everybody likes now,

I don't like it but when
nobody liked it,

that's when I was a big fan.
Oh, aren't I cool."

That's the thing I think that we
all center on as being like,

"Eww. Hipsters.
What rubbish people."

But I have to be honest
with myself and think,
"Have I ever been that person?

Have I ever been in the
situation where I'm like,

'Ooh! I liked that thing before everybody else did.
Doesn't that make me cool?'"

And honestly, I have. I feel like as much as
I can try to point out and justify

the things about me that aren't
hipster-esque and be like,

"No, hipsters are like this,
and I don't do that sort of thing,"

there is a nugget in my heart that
is enjoying things ironically.

There is definitely a sense of comfort
that I get when I am in a warehouse

that's been converted to a coffee shop,
surrounded by lots of trendy looking people.

I feel at home in that--
they're cozy!
They do a good job decorating.

I think if there is a moral
to be found here,

I don't want to find it because the moral is that
I think there's probably--there's either -

this will be more comfortable - there's either
a little bit more hipster in all of us

or there is a little bit of hipster
in me, specifically,

and I am a hipster but I don't want
to have to deal with that

and the consequences
of being that person.

I could, at least, be the first
person who will actually admit

that they are a bit of a hipster as
opposed to all of the other hipsters

that don't want to admit it.
There we go.
That's how I can feel superior.
Alright. Charlie out.

STEPHEN FRY VOICE: You've just had the almost
imponderable joy of watching charlieissocoollike,
which makes you, like, cool.

Okie dokie, last week's video
in case you missed it,

which is likely because of the way that
YouTube works these days. Hahahaha.

And, also, the trailer for my new
short film because, you know,

I will continue to promote this
until everyone on the planet

has seen it because that's what
you do when you make a film.

Thank you very much for sticking around.
Have a nice day.

comments.author: Sopwithcamel

comments.text:
You do realize, don`t you, that the reason these hipster kind of people - 
whatever they are - gets to you so much, is because you feel.. or raher 
felt (back when you couldn`t afford designer glasses, go to trendy cafe`s 
and so on) that they were dangling what they had, or how quickly they 
caught up on a trend, in front of your face. And because of that you felt 
they were mocking you, or looking down on you. While what they were 
actually doing, was reveal their personal insecurities, by their need to 
show off in front of you. Similarly those who branded them hipsters 
originally, and everyone who has continued the tradition since, expose 
their personal insecurities, by doing so.

People who truely feel confident in who they are, neither feel threatened 
nor inferior in the company of people who either believes themselves to be 
better than them, or demonstratively display an affluent lifestyle, or in 
other ways tries to convey superiority, like intellectual capacity, 
physical strength, beauty/sex appeal, a talent for humour etc etc.

It also works the other way around. Truely confident people don`t have a 
need to feel superior to others, no matter how successful, rich, smart or 
whatever is so great about them, they are. And they are more likely to want 
to talk to you about your interests and life, than brag about their Phillip 
Patek watch, sports and luxery cars, exclusive hollidays or whatever it 
might be, should you find yourself talking to one someday.

People who truely are confident in who they are, usually are a joy to meet, 
cause their interst in others is to get to know them, have interesting and 
fun conversations - not to use as an audience for lectures of their success 
in life. Those who have a need for that, and there are quite a few of those 
among the super successful ones as well, do it out of a need to compensate 
some form of personal inferiority. Their experience of feeling confident 
and well - is dependent of someone else to feel inferior to them, belittled 
or insiginficant. People having to go through life on other people`s 
expence, so to speak, I feel more sorry for, than angry with..﻿

comments.text:
You're not alone Charlie. I tend to do a bit of the things that a hipster 
would tend to do (according to the trend). One major thing being liking 
things ironically. I can't help it. It happens. But I also find myself 
liking some mainstream things (perhaps not music wise but maybe a t.v. 
show). So If society is going to regard this as a "hipster" characteristic 
(which may or not exist depending on the context or perspective of a 
person). I too have a bit of hipster inside me. But I won't let it fully 
define me. I also don't think there is anything wrong with having those 
"hipster" like qualities. By the way, Charlie you look awesome in those 
glasses.﻿

comments.author: Abigail Thompson (Spengles)

comments.text:
Okay, so I've never been like: Oh! I'm cool because I liked this thing 
before everyone else!, but I have found myself thinking: Oh! I liked this 
before everyone else did and they mocked me, I should be the cool one. But 
also I thing: Well, now that everyone likes it, I don't like it, I just got 
bored of it (or bored about everybody talking about it). I haven't found 
myself wearing Ray Ban glasses, but that is probably because I have a 
perfect eyesight. I like hipster outfits that I don't wear because just 
because I can't be bothered & I do like things ironically which deep down I 
think they're funny and I like them & I love vintage stuff and kitsch 
stuff. I would never define myself as a hipster, but I'm happy if being one 
is exacly the way I am and I'm not going to stop liking Apple because of 
that, and I think that if a hipster was ever told the he or she is one, 
then he should be proud of it because "everyone" dislikes hipsters because, 
let's face it, they are cool (at least that's my opinion - not that anyone 
cares). 
Ps. Long text, sorry.﻿
